Pre-Game Insights: Namibia's participation in the next edition is in serious jeopardy unless they can turn their form around.
Zimbabwe have had a mixed return to international football since their ban imposed by FIFA was lifted last year.
Namibia have beaten Zimbabwe in six straight encounters prior to this one.

Zimbabwe's winless run includes a 2-0 loss to Kenya at the COSAFA Cup last year and back-to-back goalless draws, again against the Harambee Stars, and then to Cameroon, in the first two rounds of this competition.

Namibia have called up several players who are currently based in South Africa for this month's qualifiers, including the likes of Orlando Pirates midfielder Deon Hotto, Sekhukhune United goalkeeper Lloydt Kazapua and Amazulu defender Riaan Hanamub.

For Zimbabwe, skipper Marvelous Nakamba has returned to the national squad for this month's qualifiers after recovering from a knee injury and subsequent surgery which kept him sidelined for over six months.
Post-Match Reflections: Given that both these sides desperately need a win, and possibly view each other as the most likely route to three points, we could see them throw caution to the wind at points in this match.
However, while we do feel there could be at least a couple of goals forthcoming in this contest, we doubt there will be anything to split these sides at the final whistle.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Namibia were forced to move their home games to neighbouring South Africa after their stadiums in Windhoek were not passed as suitable for World Cup qualifiers by the Confederation of African Football.
Despite both these nations bordering South Africa and having many citizens in the country, the match will be played behind closed doors at the request of Namibia.
